abstracts.cdata!:
The Azerbaijan Urgent Environmental
            Investment Project had a satisfactory outcome, likely
            sustainability, modest institutional development impact, and
            satisfactory Bank and Borrower performances. Lessons from
            the project are: 1) Having a diligent and flexible approach
            to implementation helps address design shortcomings and
            reorients the project to achieve development objectives. 2)
            Put in place institutional structures to sustain project
            activities early during project implementation, and phase in
            their independence instead of suddenly cutting them off from
            financial and technical support when the project closes. 3)
            Clearly identify desired outcomes in pilot activities and
            include follow-up. 4)When remediating contaminated land,
            identify and address institutional aspects such as land
            ownership and land use planning up-front to avoid illegal
            land occupation. 5) Clarity regarding fiduciary
            responsibilities, is important when an agency other than the
            parent Ministry is responsible for implementing one
            component. 6) Be realistic regarding how quickly it is
            possible to transform activities and institutions that were
            historically state-operated to a model based on a
            commercial, market-based approach. 7) Capacity building
            needs to address development of professional management
            capability, not just technical aspects. 8) For technical
            assistance to be effective, the government and implementing
            agencies have to regard it as useful for achieving highly
            desired outcomes. In this project, technical assistance
            effectively supported implementation and built local
            capacity through on-the-job training.
